{{for|the American bowler|George Pappas (bowler)}} {{Infobox philosopher |region = Western philosophy |era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] |image = |name = George Sotiros Pappas |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1942}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |school_tradition = |main_interests = [[Epistemology]], early [[Modern philosophy]], [[George Berkeley|Berkeley]] scholarship |notable_ideas = |influences = |influenced = |signature = |awards = International Berkeley Essay Prize (1993), Emeritus Professor }} '''George Sotiros Pappas''' (born 1942) is a professor of [[philosophy]] at [[Ohio State University]].[http://philosophy.osu.edu/people/person.cfm?ID=1292 Departmental profile at OSU] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070914084237/http://philosophy.osu.edu/people/person.cfm?ID=1292 |date=2007-09-14 }} Pappas specializes in [[epistemology]], the history of [[early modern philosophy]], [[philosophy of religion]], and [[metaphysics]]. He is of Greek and English origin. He is the author of the [[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] entry on [[Internalism and externalism|Internalist versus Externalist]] conceptions of [[Theory of justification|epistemic justification]].[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/justep-intext/ Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy article] He was co-editor (with [[Marshall Swain]]) of ''Essays on Knowledge and Justification'' (1978), regarded as a key anthology of essays relating to the [[Gettier problem]][http://www.iep.utm.edu/g/gettier.htm#H15 Gettier Problem bibliography at the Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy] and used as a core text in undergraduate [[epistemology]] courses.[http://www.ditext.com/clay/morris1.html Suggested epistemology reading list] George Pappas is an editorial consultant of [[Berkeley Studies]].{{cite web | url = http://people.hsc.edu/berkeleystudies/editorial.php | title = Berkeley Studies: Editorial Staff | accessdate = 2011-01-16 | year = | publisher = [[Hampden–Sydney College]] }} == Studies in Berkeley's philosophy == George S. Pappas is known to be a leading Berkeley scholar; his essay "Berkeley and Scepticism"{{cite journal |last=Pappas |first=G.S. |title=Berkeley and Scepticism |journal=[[Philosophy and Phenomenological Research]] |volume=59 |issue=1 |pages=133–149 |year=1999 |doi= 10.2307/2653461|url=}} was in 1993 awarded the International Berkeley Prize.See: [http://www.rochester.edu/college/PHL/Berkeleywinners.html Berkeley Prize Winners].
The annual International Berkeley Essay Prize competition was established by [[Colin Murray Turbayne]] and his wife in 1990. Professor Pappas is a regular participant of International Berkeley Conferences.[http://georgeberkeley.tamu.edu/conferences.html International Berkeley Conferences] {{webarchive|url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160518110950/http://georgeberkeley.tamu.edu/conferences.html |date=2016-05-18 }} At one such conference, celebrating the 300th anniversary of George Berkeley's birth, Mr. Pappas propounded a new approach to the relationship between Berkeley's anti-abstractionism and "esse est percipi"To be is to be perceived. A core proposition of Berkeley's ontology. principle. On Pappas reading, Berkeley's two theses — that there are no abstract ideas and that sensible objects must be perceived in order to exist — entail one another.{{cite conference |last=Pappas |first=G.S. |chapter=Abstract ideas and the 'esse is percipi' thesis |editor-first=D. |editor-last=Berman |title=George Berkeley: Essays and replies |publisher=Irish Academic Press |location=Dublin |year=1985 |isbn=0-7165-2395-7 |pages=47–62 |conference=Proceedings of International Berkeley Conference in Dublin, 1985 |ref={{harvid|Essays and replies|1985}}}} {{quote|text = Pappas' formulation of the relationship between these two propositions is ingenious and merits his verdict that it is a 'very exciting result' ... So far as I know, his thesis is original. Some writers, to be sure, have some close to suggesting that the first proposition is a necessary condition for the truth of the second, but I cannot think of a commentator who holds that it is both a necessary and sufficient condition. |author= Avrum Stroll |source= Two lines of argumentation in Berkeley's ''Principles'': a reply to George Pappas. In {{harvnb|Essays and replies|1985|p=140}}}} Pappas' interpretation of Berkeley's '''esse'' is ''percipi''' thesis has sparked much discussion.{{cite journal| last=Stroll |first=Avrum |title=Two lines of argumentation in Berkeley's Principles: a reply to George S. Pappas}} In {{harvnb|Essays and replies|1985|pp=139–145}}McKim, Robert. "Abstraction and Immaterialism: Recent Interpretations" // [[Berkeley Studies|Berkeley Newsletter]] 15 (1997–1998): 1–13. In 1989, the Garland Publishing Company brought out a 15-volume collection of major works on Berkeley; Pappas' paper "Abstract ideas and the 'esse is percipi' thesis" was included in the third volume,Berkeley on abstraction and abstract ideas / Ed. by W. Doney — N.Y.; L.: Garland, 1989. — XVII, 434 p. — (Philosophy of George Berkeley; 3; A Garland series) as it was considered to be a significant contribution to Berkeley scholarship. Pappas developed his treatment of Berkeley's "esse est percipi" principle{{harvnb|Pappas|2000|pp=255–8. Ind.: p.257–261. (See chapter 5 ''Esse is percipi principle'')}} to repudiate the "inherence interpretation of Berkeley", upon which Edwin E. Allaire, among others, elaborated{{cite journal |last1=Allaire |first1=Edwin B. |year=1963 |title=Berkeley's Idealism |journal=[[Theoria (philosophy journal)|Theoria]] |volume=XXIX |issue=3 |pages=229–44 |format=DjVu |accessdate=2011-01-16 |url=http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6138_Allaire_Berkeley_s_idealism.djvu |doi=10.1111/j.1755-2567.1963.tb00025.x |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306000503/http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6138_Allaire_Berkeley_s_idealism.djvu |archivedate=2012-03-06 |df= }}
The article is a classical work of Berkeley scholarship.For more detail, see: *{{cite journal |last=Hausman |first=A. |title=Adhering to inherence: A new look at the old steps in Berkeley's march to idealism |journal=[[Canadian Journal of Philosophy]] |volume=14 |issue=3 |pages=421–443 |year=1984 |doi= 10.1080/00455091.1984.10716390|url= |ref=harv}} (A wide grasp of literature on the "inherence account".) *{{cite book |first=Robert G. |last=Muehlmann |chapter=Introduction |title=Berkeley's Metaphysics: Structural, Interpretive, and Critical Essays |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zrvNFjIrDMUC |year=2010 |origyear=1995 |publisher=Pennsylvania State Press |isbn=0-271-04228-1}} (Muehlmann's Introduction provides further bibliographical information of the various articles in defense and in criticism of this view.) *{{cite book |first=Katia |last=Saporiti |chapter=Ch. IV §2 Die Inhärenzhypothese |title=Die Wirklichkeit der Dinge: eine Untersuchung des Begriffs der Idee in der Philosophie George Berkeleys |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kS1Ux2jxMIMC&pg=PP1 |year=2006 |publisher=Vittorio Klostermann |isbn=978-3-465-03510-7 }} For up-to-date criticism of the "inherence account," see: {{cite journal |last1=Bettcher |first1=Talia Mae (Ph. D., [[California State University, Los Angeles]]) |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor-last= |editor-first= |editor-link= |date=November 2008 |title=Berkeley's Dualistic Ontology |journal=[[Análisis Filosófico]] |volume=28 |issue=2 |series= |pages=147–174 |publisher= |isbn= |pmid= |pmc= |bibcode= |doi= |accessdate= |url=http://www.calstatela.edu/faculty/tbettch/BerkeleyDualism.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319211851/http://www.calstatela.edu/faculty/tbettch/BerkeleyDualism.pdf |archivedate=2012-03-19 |ref= |deadurl=yes |df= }}
That account is put forward to answer an extremely perplexing question in the history of philosophy: Why did Berkeley embrace idealism, i. e., why did he hold that esse est percipi, that to be is to be perceived? {{harv|Hausman|1984|pp=421–2}}
After emerging in the early 1960s, the "inherence account" attracted numerous proponents and became an influential element of contemporary Berkeley scholarship. In his paper "Ideas, minds, and Berkeley"{{cite journal|last=Pappas |first=G.S. |title=Ideas, minds, and Berkeley |journal=[[American Philosophical Quarterly|Am. Phil. Q.]] |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=181–194 |year=1980 |doi= |url=http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6145_Pappas_Ideas%2C_Minds%2C_and_Berkeley.djvu |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306000509/http://su-ltd.mylivepage.ru/file/2716/6145_Pappas_Ideas,_Minds,_and_Berkeley.djvu |archivedate=2012-03-06 |df= }} Pappas revealed some discrepancies between fountain-head evidences and Allaire's approach to a reconstruction of Berkeley's idealism. Pappas' critical examination of the "inherence account" is greatly appreciated by Berkeley scholars. Pappas' penetrating remarks compelled Edwin B. Allaire to revise and improve his conception.{{cite book |last=Allaire |first=Edwin B. |chapter=Berkeley's Idealism Revisited |editor-first=Colin M. |editor-last=Turbayne |title=Berkeley: Critical and Interpretive Essays |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RExF10reT9wC |year=1982 |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |isbn=978-0-8166-1066-2 |pages=197–206}} Even those who share Allaire's account of Berkeley's idealism acknowledge Pappas' article to be "an excellent review and critique of the IA [inherence account]."{{harvnb|Hausman|1984|p=422 (note 2)}} In 2000 George Pappas published his monograph ''Berkeley's thought'' in which some parts were based on earlier papers of his. While writings by [[A. A. Luce]] or [[Geoffrey Warnock]] are long out dated, the book ''Berkeley's thought'' written by Dr Pappas is often included in lists of recommended literature on [[George Berkeley|Berkeley]]'s philosophy.As examples, take: * {{cite book | last = Bettcher | first = Talia Mae | title = Berkeley: A Guide for the Perplexed | series = Guides for the Perplexed | publisher = [[Continuum International Publishing Group|Continuum Publishing]] | isbn = 0-8264-8991-5 | page = 208 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Downing | first1 = Lisa | editor-last = Zalta | editor-first = Edward N. | date = Winter 2008 | title = George Berkeley | journal = The [[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] | url = http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/berkeley/ }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Flage | first1 = Daniel E. | title = George Berkeley (1685–1753) | journal = The [[Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] | url = http://www.iep.utm.edu/berkeley/ | year = 2005 }} == Publications == *{{cite book |first=George S. |last=Pappas |title=Berkeley's Thought |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gTkpVbFW9OMC |year=2000 |publisher=Cornell University Press |isbn=0-8014-3700-8 |ref=harv}} ==See also== * [[American philosophy]] * [[List of American philosophers]] * [[George Berkeley]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pappas, George}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:American philosophers]] [[Category:Epistemologists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ohio State University faculty]] [[Category:George Berkeley scholars]]

'''Henri René Albert Guy de Maupassant''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|oʊ|p|ə|ˌ|s|ɑː|n|t}};<ref>[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/maupassant "Maupassant"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''.</ref> {{IPA-fr|ɡid(ə) mopasɑ̃|lang}}; 5 August 1850 – 6 July 1893) was a [[19th-century French literature|French writer]], remembered as a master of the [[short story]] form, and as a representative of the [[Naturalism (literature)|naturalist]] school of writers, who depicted human lives and destinies and social forces in disillusioned and often pessimistic terms.

Maupassant was a [[protégé]] of [[Gustave Flaubert]] and his stories are characterized by economy of style and efficient, effortless ''dénouements'' ([[outcome (game theory)|outcomes]]). Many are set during the [[Franco-Prussian War]] of the 1870s, describing the futility of war and the innocent civilians who, caught up in events beyond their control, are permanently changed by their experiences. He wrote some 300 short stories, six novels, three travel books, and one volume of verse. His first published story, "[[Boule de Suif]]" ("Ball of Fat", 1880), is often considered his masterpiece.

=Biography=
[[File:Maupassant 7 ans.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Guy de Maupassant 7 years old]]

Henri-René-Albert-Guy de Maupassant was born 5 August 1850 at the ''Château de Miromesnil'' (Castle Miromesnil, near [[Dieppe, Seine-Maritime|Dieppe]] in the [[Seine-Inférieure]] (now [[Seine-Maritime]]) department in France. He was the first son of Laure Le Poittevin and Gustave de Maupassant, both from prosperous bourgeois families. His mother urged his father when they married in 1846 to obtain the right to use the [[Nobiliary particle|particule]] or form "de Maupassant" instead of "Maupassant" as his family name, in order to indicate noble birth.<ref name="Gicquel 1993 p12">Alain-Claude Gicquel, ''Maupassant, tel un météore'', Le Castor Astral, 1993, p. 12</ref> Gustave discovered a certain Jean-Baptiste Maupassant, ''conseiller-secrétaire'' to the King, who was ennobled in 1752.<ref name="Gicquel 1993 p12"/> He then obtained from the ''Tribunal Civil'' of Rouen by decree dated 9 July 1846 the right to style himself "de Maupassant" instead of "Maupassant" and this was his surname at the birth of his son Guy in 1850.<ref name="Gicquel 1993 p12"/>

When Maupassant was 11 and his brother Hervé was five, his mother, an independent-minded woman, risked social disgrace to obtain a legal separation from her husband, who was violent towards her.

After the separation, Laure Le Poittevin kept her two sons. With the father's absence, Maupassant's mother became the most influential figure in the young boy's life.<ref>{{cite web|title=Guy de Maupassant Biography|url=http://www.enotes.com/topics/guy-de-maupassant|website=enotes|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref> She was an exceptionally well-read woman and was very fond of classical literature, particularly [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]. Until the age of thirteen, Guy happily lived with his mother, at [[Étretat]], in the Villa des Verguies, where, between the sea and the luxuriant countryside, he grew very fond of fishing and outdoor activities. At age thirteen, his mother next placed her two sons as day boarders in a private school, the Institution Leroy-Petit, in Rouen—the ''Institution Robineau'' of Maupassant's story ''La Question du Latin''—for classical studies.<ref>Maupassant, ''Choix de Contes'', Cambridge, p. viii, 1945</ref> From his early education he retained a marked hostility to religion, and to judge from verses composed around this time he deplored the ecclesiastical atmosphere, its ritual and discipline.<ref>{{cite book|last1=de Maupassant|first1=Guy|title=Le Horla et autres contes d'angoisse|date=1984|publisher=Flammarion|location=Paris|isbn=978-2-0807-1300-1|page=233|edition=2006|language=French}}</ref> Finding the place to be unbearable, he finally got himself expelled in his next-to-last year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Biographie de Guy de Maupassant|url=http://www.alalettre.com/maupassant-bio.php|website=@lalettre.com|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref>

In 1867, as he entered junior high school, Maupassant made acquaintance with [[Gustave Flaubert]] at Croisset at the insistence of his mother.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/369995/Guy-de-Maupassant|title= Maupassant's Apprenticeship with Flaubert}}</ref> Next year, in autumn, he was sent to the ''[[Lycée Pierre-Corneille]]'' in Rouen<ref name="LyCo6">{{cite web|url=http://lgcorneille-lyc.spip.ac-rouen.fr/spip.php?article6 |title=Lycée Pierre Corneille de Rouen - History |publisher=Lgcorneille-lyc.spip.ac-rouen.fr |date=1944-04-19 |accessdate=2018-03-13}}</ref> where he proved a good scholar indulging in poetry and taking a prominent part in theatricals. In October 1868, at the age of 18, he saved the famous poet [[Algernon Charles Swinburne]] from drowning off the coast of Étretat.<ref>Clyde K. Hyder, ''Algernon Swinburne: The Critical Heritage'', 1995, p. 185</ref>

The [[Franco-Prussian War]] broke out soon after his graduation from college in 1870; he enlisted as a volunteer. In 1871, he left Normandy and moved to Paris where he spent ten years as a clerk in the Navy Department. During this time his only recreation and relaxation was boating on the [[Seine]] on Sundays and holidays.

Gustave Flaubert took him under his protection and acted as a kind of literary guardian to him, guiding his debut in journalism and literature. At Flaubert's home, he met [[Émile Zola]] and the Russian novelist [[Ivan Turgenev]], as well as many of the proponents of the [[realism (arts)|realist]] and [[naturalism (literature)|naturalist]] schools. He wrote and played himself in a comedy in 1875 (with the benediction of Flaubert), "[[:fr:À la feuille de rose, maison turque|À la feuille de rose, maison turque]]".

In 1878, he was transferred to the Ministry of Public Instruction and became a contributing editor to several leading newspapers such as ''[[Le Figaro]]'', ''[[Gil Blas (periodical)|Gil Blas]]'', ''[[Le Gaulois]]'' and ''[[l'Écho de Paris]]''. He devoted his spare time to writing novels and short stories.

In 1880 he published what is considered his first masterpiece, "[[Boule de Suif]]", which met with instant and tremendous success. Flaubert characterized it as "a masterpiece that will endure." This was Maupassant's first piece of short fiction set during the Franco-Prussian War, and was followed by short stories such as "[[Deux Amis]]", "[[Mother Savage]]", and "[[Mademoiselle Fifi (short story)|Mademoiselle Fifi]]".

The decade from 1880 to 1891 was the most fertile period of Maupassant's life. Made famous by his first short story, he worked methodically and produced two or sometimes four volumes annually. His talent and practical business sense made him wealthy.

In 1881 he published his first volume of short stories under the title of ''La Maison Tellier''; it reached its twelfth edition within two years. In 1883 he finished his first novel, ''Une Vie'' (translated into English as ''A Woman's Life''), 25,000 copies of which were sold in less than a year. His second novel ''[[Bel Ami]]'', which came out in 1885, had thirty-seven printings in four months.

[[File:Guy de Maupassant photo portrait young.jpg|thumb|Guy de Maupassant early in his career.]]
His editor, Havard, commissioned him to write more stories, and Maupassant continued to produce them efficiently and frequently. At this time he wrote what many consider to be his greatest novel, ''[[Pierre et Jean]]''.

With a natural aversion to society, he loved retirement, solitude, and meditation. He traveled extensively in [[Algeria]], Italy, England, [[Brittany]], [[Sicily]], [[Auvergne (province)|Auvergne]], and from each voyage brought back a new volume. He cruised on his private yacht ''Bel-Ami'', named after his novel. This life did not prevent him from making friends among the literary celebrities of his day: [[Alexandre Dumas, fils]] had a paternal affection for him; at [[Aix-les-Bains]] he met [[Hippolyte Taine]] and became devoted to the philosopher-historian.

Flaubert continued to act as his literary godfather. His friendship with the [[Edmond Louis Antoine Huot de Goncourt|Goncourts]] was of short duration; his frank and practical nature reacted against the ambiance of gossip, scandal, duplicity, and invidious criticism that the two brothers had created around them in the guise of an 18th-century style salon.

Maupassant was one of a fair number of 19th-century Parisians (including [[Charles Gounod]], [[Alexandre Dumas, fils]], and [[Charles Garnier (architect)|Charles Garnier]]) who did not care for the [[Eiffel Tower]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mariogagliardi.com/index.php?/archives/43-The-Tower-of-Babel-Gustave-Eiffel-and-the-creation-of-modernity.html|title=The Tower of Babel - ''Criticism of Eiffel Tower''|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013202211/http://mariogagliardi.com/index.php?%2Farchives%2F43-The-Tower-of-Babel-Gustave-Eiffel-and-the-creation-of-modernity.html|archivedate=13 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He often ate lunch in the restaurant at its base, not out of preference for the food but because it was only there that he could avoid seeing its otherwise unavoidable profile.<ref>Barthes, Roland. ''The Eiffel Tower and Other Mythologies''. Tr. Howard, Richard. Berkeley: [[University of California Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-520-20982-4}}. Page 1.</ref> He and forty-six other Parisian literary and artistic notables attached their names to an elaborately irate letter of protest against the tower's construction, written to the Minister of Public Works.

Maupassant also wrote under several [[pseudonym]]s such as Joseph Prunier, Guy de Valmont, and Maufrigneuse (which he used from 1881 to 1885).

In his later years he developed a constant desire for solitude, an obsession for self-preservation, and a fear of death and paranoia of persecution caused by the [[syphilis]] he had contracted in his youth. It has been suggested that his brother, Hervé, also suffered from syphilis and the disease may have been congenital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/arts/highlights/000808_maupassant.shtml |title=Remembering Maupassant | Arts and Entertainment | BBC World Service |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2000-08-09 |accessdate=2018-03-13}}</ref> On 2 January 1892, Maupassant tried to commit suicide by cutting his throat, and was committed to the private asylum of Esprit Blanche at [[Passy]], in Paris, where he died 6 July 1893.

Guy De Maupassant penned his own [[epitaph]]: "I have coveted everything and taken pleasure in nothing." He is buried in Section 26 of the [[Montparnasse Cemetery]], Paris.

==Significance==
Maupassant is considered one of the fathers of the modern short story. He delighted in clever plotting, and served as a model for [[Somerset Maugham]] and [[O. Henry]] in this respect. One of his famous short stories, "[[The Necklace]]", was imitated with a twist by both Maugham ("Mr Know-All", "A String of Beads") and [[Henry James]] ("[[Paste (story)|Paste]]").

Taking his cue from [[Balzac]], Maupassant wrote comfortably in both the high-[[Realism (literature)|Realist]] and [[fantasy|fantastic]] modes; stories and novels such as "L'Héritage" and ''Bel-Ami'' aim to recreate [[French Third Republic|Third Republic]] France in a realistic way, whereas many of the short stories (notably "[[Le Horla]]" and "Qui sait?") describe apparently supernatural phenomena.

The supernatural in Maupassant, however, is often implicitly a symptom of the protagonists' troubled minds; Maupassant was fascinated by the burgeoning discipline of [[psychiatry]], and attended the public lectures of [[Jean-Martin Charcot]] between 1885 and 1886.<ref>Pierre Bayard, ''Maupassant, juste avant Freud'' (Paris: Minuit, 1998)</ref>

==Legacy==
[[Leo Tolstoy]] used Maupassant as the subject for one of his essays on art: ''[[s:The Works of Guy de Maupassant|The Works of Guy de Maupassant]]''. His stories are second only to Shakespeare in their inspiration of movie adaptations with films ranging from ''[[Stagecoach (1939 film)|Stagecoach]]'', ''[[Citizen Kane]]'', ''[[Oyuki the Virgin]]'' and ''[[Masculine Feminine]]''.<ref name="Richard Brody New Yorker">{{cite news|url= http://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/the-writer-who-sparks-the-finest-movie-adaptations|author = [[Richard Brody]]|title=The Writer Who Sparks the Finest Movie Adaptations| date=26 October 2015|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]| accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref>

[[Friedrich Nietzsche]]'s [[Ecce Homo (Nietzsche)|autobiography]] mentions him in the following text:

"I cannot at all conceive in which century of history one could haul together such inquisitive and at the same time delicate psychologists as one can in contemporary Paris: I can name as a sample – for their number is by no means small, ... or to pick out one of the stronger race, a genuine Latin to whom I am particularly attached, Guy de Maupassant."

[[William Saroyan]] wrote a short story about Maupassant in his 1971 book, ''[[Letters from 74 rue Taitbout]] or Don't Go But If You Must Say Hello To Everybody''.

[[Isaac Babel]] wrote a short story about him, “Guy de Maupassant.” It appears in ''The Collected Stories of Isaac Babel'' and in the story anthology ''You’ve Got To Read This: Contemporary American Writers Introduce Stories that Held Them in Awe.''

[[Gene Roddenberry]], in an early draft for ''[[The Questor Tapes]]'', wrote a scene in which the [[Android (robot)|android]] ''Questor'' employs Maupassant's theory that, "the human female will open her mind to a man to whom she has opened other channels of communications." In the script Questor copulates with a woman to obtain information that she is reluctant to impart. Due to complaints from [[NBC]] executives, this part of the script was never filmed.<ref>[Quoted from the track "The Questor Affair" from the album ''[[Inside Star Trek]]''.]</ref>

[[Michel Drach]] directed and co-wrote a 1982 French [[biographical film]]: ''Guy de Maupassant''. [[Claude Brasseur]] stars as the titular character.

'''Gheorghe "Gică" Hagi''' ({{IPA-ro|ˈɡe̯orɡe ˈhad͡ʒi|-|Ro-Gheorghe Hagi.ogg}}; born 5 February 1965) is a Romanian former professional [[association football|footballer]], considered one of the best [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]]s in Europe during the 1980s and '90s<ref name="planetworldcup.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.planetworldcup.com/LEGENDS/hagi.html|title=Gheorghe Hagi|work=Planet World Cup.com}}</ref> and the greatest Romanian footballer of all time.<ref>[http://www.romania-insider.com/famous-romanians-gheorghe-hagi/5870/# "Famous Romanians: Gheorghe Hagi"]. ''Romania Insider''. 11 August 2010.</ref> [[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray]] fans called him "''Comandante''" ("The Commander") and Romanians call him "''Regele''" ("The King").<ref name="Romania and Gala’s commander and king"/> He is currently the owner and manager of [[FC Viitorul Constanța|Viitorul Constanța]].

Nicknamed "The [[Diego Maradona|Maradona]] of the [[Carpathian Mountains|Carpathians]]", Hagi is considered a hero in his homeland. He was named [[Romanian Footballer of the Year]] seven times, and is regarded as one of the best football players of his generation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gandul.info/sport-miscare/hagi-locul-35-topul-celor-buni-fotbalisti-secolului-1029680|title=Hagi, pe locul 35 în topul celor mai buni fotbaliști ai secolului|language=Romanian|date=7 November 2007}}</ref><ref name=soccer>{{cite web|url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/TeamHons/HonsWldSocPlyrsCent.html|title=World Soccer 100 Players of the Century|work=England Football Online}}</ref> As a creative advanced [[playmaker]], he was renowned for his dribbling, technique, vision, passing and finishing.<ref name="Romania and Gala’s commander and king">[https://www.fifa.com/fifa-tournaments/players-coaches/people=2354/profile.html "Romania and Gala’s commander and king"]. [[FIFA]].com. Retrieved 18 November 2013</ref><ref name="FIFA Profile">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/players/player=2354/|title=Gheorghe HAGI|publisher=FIFA.com|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref>

Hagi played for the [[Romanian national football team|Romanian national team]] in three [[FIFA World Cup]]s, in [[1990 FIFA World Cup|1990]], [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]] (where he was named in the [[FIFA World Cup awards#All-Star Team|World Cup All-Star Team]]) and [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998]]; as well as in three [[UEFA European Championship]]s, in [[UEFA Euro 1984|1984]], [[UEFA Euro 1996|1996]] and [[UEFA Euro 2000|2000]]. He won a total of 125 caps for Romania, ranked second after [[Dorinel Munteanu]], and is the joint leading goalscorer (alongside [[Adrian Mutu]]) with 35 goals.

In November 2003, to celebrate [[UEFA]]'s Jubilee, Hagi was selected as the [[UEFA Jubilee Awards|Golden Player]] of Romania by the [[Romanian Football Federation]] as their most outstanding player of the past 50 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefa/news/Kind=256/newsId=130150.html |title=Golden Players take centre stage |work=UEFA.com |date=29 November 2003 |accessdate=4 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040312203128/http://www.uefa.com/uefa/news/Kind%3D256/newsId%3D130150.html |deadurl=yes |archivedate=12 March 2004 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2004, he was named by [[Pelé]] as one of the [[FIFA 100|125 Greatest Living Footballers]] at a [[FIFA]] Awards Ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/3533891.stm |title=Pele's list of the greatest |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 March 2004 |accessdate=18 November 2013 }}</ref> He was listed at number 25 in ''[[World Soccer Magazine]]''{{'}}s list of the 100 greatest players of the 20th century.<ref name=soccer/> Hagi is one of the few footballers to have played for both Spanish rival clubs [[Real Madrid]] and [[Barcelona FC]].

In 2009, Hagi founded Romanian club [[FC Viitorul Constanța|Viitorul Constanța]]. He is currently both owner and chairman of the club. Hagi also established the [[Gheorghe Hagi Football Academy]], one of the largest and most successful football academies in [[Southeastern Europe]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gsp.ro/fotbal/liga-1/reportaj-exclusiv-suma-fabuloasa-pe-care-gica-hagi-a-investit-o-in-academie-si-facilitatile-incredibile-din-complex-453588.html |title=Suma fabuloasă pe care Gică Hagi a investit-o în Academie şi facilităţile incredibile din complex |publisher=[[Gazeta Sporturilor]] |language=Romanian |date=10 July 2015 |accessdate=11 July 2015}}</ref>

==Club career==
Born in [[Săcele, Constanța|Săcele]], Hagi started his career playing for the youth teams of [[SSC Farul Constanța|Farul Constanța]] in the 1970s, before being selected by the [[Romanian Football Federation]] to join the squad of Luceafărul București in 1980 for two years. In 1982, he returned to [[Constanța]], but one year later, aged 18, he was prepared to make the step to a top team. He was originally directed to [[CS Universitatea Craiova|Universitatea Craiova]], but chose [[FC Sportul Studențesc București|Sportul Studențesc]] of [[Bucharest]] instead.

In late 1987, Hagi transferred to [[FC Steaua București|Steaua București]] as the team prepared for their [[UEFA Super Cup|European Super Cup]] final against [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]]. The original contract was for one game only, the final. However, after winning the trophy, where Hagi scored the only goal of the match, Steaua did not want to release him back to Sportul Studențesc and retained him. During his Steaua years (1987–1990), Hagi played 97 [[Liga I]] games, scoring 76 goals. He and the team reached the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] semi-final in [[1987–88 European Cup|1988]] and the [[1989 European Cup Final|final]] in the following year, while Hagi finished as one of the competition's top scorers in the former edition of the tournament. Hagi and Steaua were the champions of Romania in 1987, 1988 and 1989 and as well as winning the [[Cupa României]] in 1987, 1988 and 1989. His strong performances had him linked with [[Arrigo Sacchi]]'s [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] and [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], but [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]]'s [[Socialist Republic of Romania|communist government]] rejected any offer.

After the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]], Hagi was signed by [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]. The [[La Liga]] side paid $4.3 million to Steaua București for him. Hagi played two seasons with Madrid, then was sold to [[Brescia Calcio|Brescia]].

Hagi began the [[1992–93 Serie A|1992–93 season]] with Brescia, but after his first season, the club was relegated to [[Serie B]]. The next season, Hagi helped the club win [[1993–94 Serie B|Serie B]] and earn promotion back to [[Serie A]]. After performing memorably during the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]], Hagi was signed by [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].

After two years at ''Barça'', Hagi signed for Turkish club [[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray]]. At Galatasaray, he was both successful and highly popular among the Turkish supporters. Hagi was an important member of a team that would win four consecutive league titles. In 2000, at age 35, Hagi had the best days of his career winning every possible trophy with Galatasaray. Gala won the [[1999–2000 UEFA Cup]] after defeating [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[2000 UEFA Cup Final|final]], a match in which Hagi was sent off for punching Arsenal captain [[Tony Adams]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sport/football/752751.stm|title=BBC News - FOOTBALL - Penalty heartbreak for Arsenal|website=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> This was followed by the capture of the [[2000 UEFA Super Cup|UEFA Super Cup]] with a historic win against Hagi's former club Real Madrid. Both feats were firsts, and remain unmatched in Turkish football history. The mass hysteria caused by these wins in [[Istanbul]] raised Hagi's popularity even further with the fans and prompted [[France national football team|French ex-international]] [[Luis Fernández]] to say, "Hagi is like wine, the older it gets, the better he is."

When he retired in 2001, Hagi remained one of the most beloved players in the Turkish and Romanian championships. Hagi is highly praised by the Galatasaray supporters. The classic chant "I Love You Hagi" was adopted by Gala fans since his arrival at Galatasaray.

==International career==
Hagi made his debut for the [[Romania national football team|Romania national team]] at age 18 in 1983 against [[Norway national football team|Norway]], in [[Oslo]]. He was part of the Romanian team until 2000.

Hagi took part at the 1990 World Cup and later led the Romanian team to its best ever international performance at the 1994 World Cup, where the team reached the quarterfinals before [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] ended their run after winning the penalty shoot-out. Hagi scored three times in the tournament, including a memorable goal in their 3–2 surprise defeat of South American powerhouse and previous runners-up [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]]. In the first of Romania's group stage matches, against [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]], Hagi scored one of the most memorable goals of that tournament, curling in a 40-yard lob over Colombian goalkeeper [[Óscar Córdoba]] who was caught out of position. He was named in the Team of the Tournament.

Four years later, after the [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998 World Cup]], Hagi decided to retire from the national team, only to change his mind after a few months and participate in [[UEFA Euro 2000]], during which he was [[sent off]] in the quarter-final loss against [[UEFA Euro 2000 Final|eventual runners-up]] [[Italy national football team|Italy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://walloffame.infostradasports.com/asp/index.asp?SortId=63|title=Wall of Fame: Gheorghe Hagi|publisher=Infostrada Sports|accessdate=13 October 2009}}</ref>

Hagi retired from professional football in 2001, age 36, in a game called "Gala Hagi" on 24 April.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/1294532.stm |title=Hagi takes an all-star bow |work=BBC Sport |date=24 April 2001 |accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref> He still holds the record as Romanian national team top scorer.

==Career as coach==

===Romania national team===
In 2001, Hagi was named the manager of the Romania national team, replacing [[Ladislau Bölöni]], who left the squad to coach [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]]. After failing to qualify the team for the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]], however, Hagi was sacked. His only notable achievement during the six months as Romania's manager was the win in [[Budapest]] against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]].

===Bursaspor===
In 2003, Hagi took over as coach of Turkish [[Süper Lig]] side [[Bursaspor]], but left the club after a disappointing start to the season.

===Galatasaray===
Hagi then became manager of Galatasaray in 2004, leading the team to the [[Turkish Cup]] in [[2005 Turkish Cup Final|2005 final]] with 5–1 as a score against [[Fenerbahçe–Galatasaray rivalry|fierce rivals]] [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]]. His contract, however, was not renewed since his team was not able to win [[2004–05 Süper Lig]] title over Fenerbahçe during the [[centennial]] of the club.

===Politehnica Timișoara===
Steaua București sought to hire Hagi in the summer of 2005, but Hagi's requested wage could not be met by the Romanian champions, and he became manager of [[FC Politehnica Timișoara|Politehnica Timișoara]] instead. However, after a string of poor results and disagreements with management, he left the club after a few months. Constanța's [[Stadionul Farul|main stadium]] used to bear his name, but the name was changed after Hagi signed with Politehnica Timișoara.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gandul.info/sport/constanta-s-lepadat-gheorghe-hagi.html?3941;253988 |title=Constanta s-a lepadat de Gheorghe Hagi |work=Gandul.info |language=Romanian |date=21 November 2005 |accessdate=4 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070701031855/http://www.gandul.info/sport/constanta-s-lepadat-gheorghe-hagi.html?3941%3B253988 |archivedate=1 July 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

===Steaua București===
From June to September 2007, Hagi coached Steaua București, had a mediocre start in the internal championship mainly due to the large number of unavailable injured players, and managed to qualify the team for the second time in line to the UEFA Champions League group stages, passing two qualifying rounds. He resigned due to a long series of conflicts with club owner [[Gigi Becali]], which also happens to be his godson. The main reason for resigning was the owner's policy of imposing players, making the team's strategy and threats. Hagi's resigned mere hours after Steaua's first Champions League match away against [[SK Slavia Prague|Slavia Prague]], a 2–1 loss.

===Galatasaray return===
After [[Frank Rijkaard]] was sacked as coach, Hagi signed a one and a half year contract with Galatasaray on 21 October 2010. His official presentation was held on 22 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.galatasaray.org/en/kulup/haber/1131.php |title=Hagi Returns to Galatasaray! |work=Galatasaray.org|date=21 October 2010}}</ref> His former teammate from Galatasaray [[Tugay Kerimoğlu]] assisted him in [[Istanbul]], but he was sacked on 22 March 2011 after a series of poor results in the Süper Lig.

==Style of play==
A talented left-footed [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]], Hagi's playing style was frequently [[New Maradona|compared]] with [[Diego Maradona]]'s throughout his career, due to his technical ability as well as his temperamental character and leadership;<ref name="treccani">{{cite web|url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/gheorghe-hagi_%28Enciclopedia-dello-Sport%29/|title=HAGI, Gheorghe|publisher=Treccani: Enciclopedia dello Sport (2002)|language=Italian|author1=Marino Bortoletti|accessdate=10 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="Gheorghe Hagi: The Maradona of the Carpathians">{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/blog/espn-fc-united-blog/68/post/2283023/gheorghe-hagi-maradona-of-the-carpathians|title=Gheorghe Hagi: The Maradona of the Carpathians|publisher=ESPN FC|date=21 May 2010|accessdate=10 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="zonacesarini">{{cite web|url=http://zonacesarini.net/2015/01/24/hagi-la-storia-del-maradona-dei-carpazi/|title=GHEORGHE HAGI: STORIA IN TRE ATTI DEL MARADONA DEI CARPAZI|publisher=ZonaCesarini.net|language=Italian|author1=Alessandro Bezzi|date=24 January 2015|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=1550830.html|title=Hagi and Tugay take Galatasaray helm|publisher=UEFA.com|date=21 October 2010|accessdate=10 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sport.sky.it/calcio/mondiali/fotogallery/2014/05/31/verso_mondiale_countdown_grandi_numeri_10.html#7|title=Mondiali, -10: Pelè, Maradona e i grandi Dieci della storia|publisher=Sky.it|language=Italian|accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref> as a youth, he was mainly inspired by compatriots [[Anghel Iordănescu]] and [[Ion Dumitru]].<ref name="Gheorghe Hagi: The Maradona of the Carpathians"/> A quick, highly creative, and mobile advanced [[playmaker]], Hagi was also tactically versatile, and capable of playing in several [[Midfielder|midfield]] and [[Forward (association football)|offensive]] positions on either [[Midfielder#Winger|wing]] or through the [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|middle]], due to his ability with both feet, despite being naturally left-footed, although he had a preference for using his stronger foot; his preferred position was in a free role as a classic number 10, but he was also used as a [[Forward (association football)#Second striker|second striker]] on occasion.<ref name="planetworldcup.com"/><ref name="Romania and Gala’s commander and king"/><ref name="zonacesarini"/><ref name="legacy">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsoccer.com/blogs/gheorghe-hagi-creating-a-new-legacy-for-romanian-football-360444|title=Gheorghe Hagi creating a new legacy for Romanian football|publisher=World Soccer|author=Jeff Prevost|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/babb/11680631/Double-trouble-why-arent-there-more-two-footed-footballers.html|title=Double trouble: why aren't there more two-footed footballers?|publisher=The Telegraph|author1=Adam Hurrey|date=20 June 2015|accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="rare No. 10">{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/club/arsenal/359/blog/post/2760447/ozil-rare-no-10-playing-for-team-not-individual-honours|title=Mesut Ozil is the rare No. 10 playing for his teammates, not individual honours|publisher=ESPN FC|author1=Michael Cox|date=17 December 2015|accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=2285189.html|title=UEFA.com's weekly wonderkid: Ianis Hagi|publisher=UEFA.com|author1=Paul-Daniel Zaharia|date=26 September 2015|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref> Hagi was renowned in particular for his first touch and speed on the ball, as well as his timing, interpretation of space, bursts of acceleration, and [[Dribbling#Association football|dribbling]] skills, which enabled him to get past defenders; he was also highly regarded for his vision and precise passing,<ref name="planetworldcup.com"/><ref name="Romania and Gala’s commander and king"/><ref name="zonacesarini"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/soccer/longterm/worldcup98/results/articles/romania_england.htm|title=Romania Stuns England in Final Minutes, 2-1|publisher=The Washington Post|author1=Steven Goff|date=23 June 1998|accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref> although he was capable of both scoring and assisting goals, and was also an accurate finisher and [[Direct free kick|set-piece]] taker, who had a penchant for scoring goals from powerful, [[Curl (football)|bending]] long range strikes.<ref name="planetworldcup.com"/><ref name="Romania and Gala’s commander and king"/><ref name="Gheorghe Hagi: The Maradona of the Carpathians"/><ref name="zonacesarini"/><ref name="legacy"/><ref name="virtuoso">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/07/27/sports/27iht-rob_12.html|title=Barcelona Adds a 3d Virtuoso|publisher=The New York Times|author1=Rob Hughes|date=27 July 1994|accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref> In spite of his small stature, Hagi possessed significant upper body strength, which, along with his control, aided him in protecting the ball from opponents, and allowed him to create space for himself or his teammates.<ref name="Gheorghe Hagi: The Maradona of the Carpathians"/><ref name="legacy"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/why-gheorghe-hagi-a-footballing-icon|title=Why Gheorghe Hagi is a footballing icon|publisher=FourFourTwo|author1=Jonathan Wilson|date=24 July 2017|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> Despite his skill and his reputation as one of the greatest [[Squad number (association football)|number 10s]] of his generation, his career was marked by inconsistency at times, and he was also considered to be a controversial player, due to his rebellious and arrogant attitude, as well as his low work-rate and lack of discipline, which led him to have several disagreements with his managers, opponents, and officials.<ref name="Gheorghe Hagi: The Maradona of the Carpathians"/><ref name="rare No. 10"/><ref name="Hagi's step too far">{{cite
